docs.lead_paragraph: After first resisting a judge's order to allow a 13-year-old in state custody to get an abortion, Gov. Jeb Bush's administration changed course on Tuesday and said it would abandon the legal fight. The reversal came a week after state lawyers went to Palm Beach County Circuit Court to stop the girl, identified as L.G., from having an abortion. Judge Ronald Alvarez agreed to delay the procedure while he weighed the facts, but ruled on Monday that the girl was competent to make decisions about her pregnancy and free to do so under the State Constitution.

headline.main: Florida Halts Fight to Bar Girl's Abortion

docs.abstract: Bush administration in Florida drops its legal challenge to Judge Ronald Alvarez's order to allow 13-year-old girl in state custody to get an abortion; Alvarez ruled that girl is competent to make decisions about her pregnancy and free to do so under State Constitution (M)
docs.snippet: After first resisting a judge's order to allow a 13-year-old in state custody to get an abortion, Gov. Jeb Bush's administration said it would abandon the legal fight.

byline.original: By ABBY GOODNOUGH; Christine Jordan Sexton contributed reporting from Tallahassee for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: A circuit court judge in Florida has ruled that a pregnant teenager in state custody can get an abortion over the state's objections, a lawyer involved in the case said Monday night. The lawyer, Howard Simon, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Florida, said the judge, Ronald Alvarez of Palm Beach County Circuit Court, ruled that the girl was competent to make decisions regarding her pregnancy and had the right to do so under the state's Constitution.

headline.main: State Judge Allows Teenager in Florida to Get an Abortion

docs.abstract: Florida Judge Ronald Alvarez rules pregnant teenager in state custody can get abortion over state's objections, finding she is competent and has right to make her own decisions; says child welfare agency, which has come under fire in recent years to losing track of children in its care, should have done more to prevent pregnancy; state has not yet decided whether to appeal; girl, who is represented by ACLU and Legal Aid Society of Palm Beach County, became pregnant after she ran away from state home in January (M)
docs.snippet: A circuit court judge has ruled that a pregnant 13-year-old in state custody can get an abortion over the state's objections, a lawyer involved in the case said.

docs.lead_paragraph: Where have all the Lassies gone? Who can forget that noble collie who had her own show on Sunday-night TV and was a kid's best friend, there for the hugging when you needed her to be? She was an honorary member of the show's perfect nuclear family -- the whey-faced Timmy, played by Jon Provost; his earnest mother, played by June Lockhart; and his levelheaded father, played by Hugh Reilly. But it was also abundantly clear that no one was thinking of inviting Lassie in for a snack of milk and Lick 'n Crunch treats (Oreo-style cookies from Three Dog Bakery, made with carob instead of chocolate, which is bad for dogs) or of decking her out in a Swarovski-crystal heart-shaped dog tag, or of painting her nails with Opi's Pawlish. You can be just as sure that Timmy wasn't saving up his allowance to buy Lassie a $14 squeaky toy Chewy Vuitton or Jimmy Chew and that his mother wasn't stretching the household budget to cover Le Chien et Le Chat cedar-scented laundry detergent. No, Lassie belonged to an honorable but almost-extinct breed of household pet, one that knew its place in the family of man. She would never have been caught dead sleeping in a customized $400 white-crackle painted dog bed with toile linens -- would never have been caught dead sleeping anywhere but outside the farmhouse screen door, keeping an ear cocked for strange sounds.
docs.snippet: Enough Hermès collars and spalike kennels. A pet is no person.

docs.lead_paragraph: PLAN B Further Thoughts on Faith. By Anne Lamott. 320 pp. Riverhead. $24.95.
docs.snippet: Anne Lamott is still thinking about her faith, her family and her thighs.
